title: 105_hr3032
content: The Construction Subcontractors Payment Protection Enhancement Act of 1998 establishes government-wide policies to ensure timely payment of contractors, subcontractors, and suppliers in federal procurement. This includes implementing statutes like the Prompt Payment Act, the Miller Act, and the Federal Acquisition Streamlining Act of 1994 through the Federal Acquisition Regulation. The Construction Subcontractors Payment Protection Enhancement Act of 1998 establishes government-wide policies for timely payment in federal procurement. Proposed regulations for implementing amendments must be published within 120 days of enactment, with a 60-day public comment period. Final regulations must be published within 180 days of enactment and take effect 30 days after publication. Additionally, related amendments to the Miller Act are included. The Miller Act is amended to improve payment bond protection by equalizing the amount of payment bond to the performance bond. It also extends payment bond protection to all subcontractors and suppliers by specifying conditions for progress payments and materials supplied. The Miller Act is amended to extend payment bond protection to all subcontractors and suppliers by specifying conditions for progress payments and materials supplied. Additionally, a provision is added to ensure that waivers of protection afforded by a payment bond are only valid if made in writing after the date a person may institute a suit under the Act. The Miller Act is further amended to modernize service of payment bond claims and eliminate delays in payment bond protection. Waivers of protection must be in writing after the date a suit can be instituted under the Act. The Miller Act is amended to streamline payment bond claims and discourage frivolous litigation by allowing suits to proceed even if filed within 90 days of the last labor or material supply, as long as a written denial of payment is received. Courts may award costs, fees, and interest for frivolous suits or groundless defenses. The Miller Act is amended to allow courts to award costs, fees, and interest for frivolous suits or groundless defenses. Contracting officers are held accountable for contracts under the Act. The Miller Act is amended to hold contracting officers accountable for obtaining and maintaining payment bonds for contracts. If a court finds that a required payment bond is not in effect due to the officer's negligence, the court may authorize a suit against the United States for the owed amount.
